arch:property.oc:show_val: This locus is the fill on the west side of the large cobble area. There are a lot of animal holes, some pottery and roots. WE found a few flat lying pot sherds but they did not indicate a surface. When the new smaller cobble and pottery area was found (L4004) in the SE corner of the trench we opened locus 4009 to peel back west of the area to find the rest of the pottery and cobbles. We eventually peeled far enough in L4009 to realize that it was identical to L4007 and closed L4007 and assigned the whole area west of the cobble surfaces L4009.
clumpy and slightly dense in some places (silt)
pottery, roots, bone, pebble, animal burrows, roots

The fill is riddled with animal holes so it is probably very mixed. There are large roots that make the soil soft in some places. There is some flat lying pottery but overall it is probably subtopsoil

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area B / Trench 4 / Locus 4007 (Locus)
